string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on Participants and sampling. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

The objectives of this lecture are to:

• Understand the difference between participants and sampling

• Develop sampling procedures

• Recognize sampling errors and bias

Why is it important to learn about participants and sampling for conducting research?

We need to know the right procedures to select participants to ensure scientific results.

We also learn about sampling because It may not be practical to test the entire population, or use the whole population in an experiment. You may also need specific groups represented.

Let’s first define a few terms.

- A participant is someone from whom data are collected or whose past behavior, performance, or characteristic is used in the a study. For example, if a researcher used all fourth-graders’ test scores from the same school in a study, each four grader is a participant.

-The sample is the group of participants from whom data are collected.

- Sampling is the procedure used to select the sample.

- The sample represents a larger group–the population. It is important to include descriptions of the characteristics of the sample, for example, age, gender, grade level, race, etc.

- The population is also called the target population (designated by N in upper case).

Next I would like to talk a little bit about sampling.

A sample should be a representation of the population from which it has been drawn.

Why is this important? Well often when researchers conduct studies using a sample they are not interested in just the results from that particular sample, they want to make generalizations to a larger group. They want to say, we found that this particular lets say a reading method resulted in gains on this sample, they want to make generalizations to a larger group about that.

It is important to distinguish the target population from the survey population or sampling frame.

As listed in this graphic, the target population in a study of beginning teachers may be beginning teachers across the United States, in all types of schools. The survey population may be a list of beginning public school teachers from 40 states. The sample (designated by n in lower case) is drawn from that list. The intent is to generalize the results to all beginning teachers but in this case, it can only be generalized to beginning public schools in the 40 states.

The steps to sampling are:

First, define the population, which group of people you want to study, for example, all middle school teachers in St. Paul Public Schools.

Second, we determine the sample size – now the sample size is based on many considerations, not the least of which is the money you may have available for conducting the study and the convenience of doing the study. Are you going to be able to go around the country to gather data for samples or are you going to be limited to your own region.

The type of sampling method also has an influence on the sample size, and the statistics then that you will ultimately be using.

The 3rd is to determine the sampling type. Are you using a random sampling procedure such as simple random, systematic, stratified, or clustered or a non random method such as purpose(ful) or convenience.

The importance of random sampling is that it helps to combat the potential of bias in selection of research subjects. Most human characteristics will distribute themselves evenly through a random sample, If it’s large enough…

We will introduce the sampling types in the next few slides.

Simple random sampling:

 

One type is called Simple random sampling, and what that means is that all members of the population have an equal and independent chance of being selected. Its like taking names out of a hat. If my target population is all 4th graders in the sate of Minnesota, I would form a sample by randomly selecting 4th graders from that group, and all 4th graders would have an equal and independent chance of being selected.

The second type, stratified random sampling, is a situation in which we create certain sub-groups in our sample that are in proportion to those numbers in the population.

For example, lets say I wanted to have sub-groups according to ethnicity, and if 10% of 4th graders in Minnesota are Hispanic American and 10% are African America and 80% are Caucasian American, the sample should be comprised of those same proportions. Again this is important when we want to ensure more sub-groups are represented. Also , when we think about doing analysis, we might want to do analysis according to those sub-groups. So we would want to make sure we have sufficient numbers of these sub-groups to make those comparisons on representative numbers in the sub-groups.

In systematic sampling you have a list, and you take a certain number by systematically going down the list. We refer to that as the Nth number. If that list is in random order to begin with, it is a random sampling method.

For example if, I’m gonna use my Minnesota 4th graders example again, if there are 10,000 4th graders in the state of Minnesota, and you want to sample 100, we begin by taking a random number, between 1-100 – we refer to that as the Nth.

So for example lets say, I take a random number between 1-100 and it is 57. I would select multiples of that, of 100, after that number so I would begin with person number 57 on the list, person number 157 on the list, 257, 357, and 457 and so on, and ultimately I would have a sample size of 100. Again, it is important that the list be in random order if it is going to be considered a random sampling method.

You might wonder why you would want to use this method, well sometimes it is used in market research (in particular).

For example, a phone company has lists and lists of phone numbers to call and marketers would use systematic random sampling technique to start on a certain number and go down the list every so many in multiples of that number that they begin with and make phone calls to customers.

Cluster sampling is the last random sampling method we are going to talk about.

This is a situation in which the unit of sampling is not the individual, but a naturally occurring group of individuals – the group being a cluster.

For example, of the 4th graders in the state of Minnesota, and we are pretending or assuming there are 345 school districts, those are the clusters, I would draw 10 districts at random and then do the study or the survey with 4th graders in just those 10 districts. The important thing is that those 10 districts were selected randomly to begin with. Cluster sampling is done quite frequently in education .

Cluster sampling has great potential for bias. Naturally occurring groups are still groups. No assurance that there won’t be similarities shared between students.
Here’s a quick review of various random sampling procedures that we have just talked about. Pause the video for a minute to review the description and examples.

Now a little bit about two non-random sampling methods, convenience sampling and purposive or purposeful.

Convenience sampling is done, as the name might suggest, as just individuals who are conveniently located to you. This is done quite frequently in education. Sampling is drawn from where you have more connections, which would allow you to do the study, in those districts as an example - that’s convenience sampling.

Purposive sampling is when you look purposefully for certain characteristics of the sample in order to do your study.

For examples, to examine the relationship between AVID program, which stands for Advancement Via Individual Determination, a college readiness program, in high school and college admission rate, we can only choose students from high schools with AVID programs.

That’s purposeful sampling.

There are a few sampling techniques for qualitative research. In this slide, we are going to focus on the most popular procedures.

First, criterion Sampling

- Participants are selected based on identified characteristics that will provide the needed information.

* Criteria are established.

* Basketball players who are college-bound seniors and at least 6 feet 5 inches tall

Snowball Sampling

- A researcher begins with a few participants and asks them to nominate or recommend others who are known to have the characteristics of interest.

* e.g., A researcher interviews school counselors who use play therapy and asks them to suggest other school counselors who they know also use play therapy.

Population validity is the sample size you need to actually represent a population with some validity. The table shows you how many subjects you need to represent.

If you population is 10, small population, you need 10 subjects.

If your population is 30, you need at least 28 subjects in your sample.

Moving down a bit, you will see you will need larger size of sample to represent you population. When you start getting up the number, for example, for 10,000 with validity, you need less than 400 people.

A lot of large polls will use a sample about 3,000 people so that they can generalize the results to population numbering in the millions.

When evaluating the sampling used in a study, it is important to keep the following points in mind so we can try to minimize possible errors and bias.

First, many research use volunteer samples. Volunteers tend to be better educated, more sociable, more unconventional, and so on.

Second, in reviewing the sample size, the general “rules of thumb” are:

- At least 30 participants for correlational studies

- At least 15 participants in each group for experimental studies

*Smaller populations require a greater proportion to be representative of the whole.

*As population increases, the proportion needed for the sample decreases.

Third, participants selected might respond in a certain way based on characteristics that determined their inclusion in the study.

- e.g., A researcher studying the effectiveness of using computer simulations to teach science, only interviews teachers who have chosen to use computer simulations because they think it is effective.

Fourth, sampling bias is a type of error that is often controlled or influenced by the researcher that leads to misleading findings. For example:

- A researcher deliberately interviews only college students in a social work program to determine the level of service to others rather than a sample of all college students

- A researcher discards participants who don’t fit the desired results.

- Researcher keeps adding participants until the desired results are achieved.

The bottom line is that most common source of sampling bias results from using non-random sampling techniques. Simple random sampling is usually best. Larger samples lead to more validity. However, due to the nature of qualitative research, large sampling is not possible. We need to try to address issues related to volunteer samples, participant motivation and sampling bias to ensure the validity of research findings.

In this video, we have reviewed:

• the difference between participants and sampling

• sampling procedures

• sampling errors and bias

This lecture provides a very high-level overview of the subject. To learn more about the sampling, please consult with your textbook.
